items.title: Making user data requests after receiving tokens from the authorization process
items.body:
I'm currently implementing user authentication using OpenID Connect and pyoidc library. I'm storing the access token and refresh token in the user's session.

As specified in the OpenID Connect specification, I can do an user data request to the `/userdata` endpoint of my authentication provider with the pyoidc provided access token.

How are user data requests made with pyoidc after the user has been successfully authenticated?

I've tried to follow the examples provided in the repository, but the data requests are made in such a manner that makes it pretty hard to get right in the first try.

This is my current piece of code:

```python
session['state'] = rndstr();
dataRequest = client.construct_UserInfoRequest(None, request_args = {
            "token": session['token']
        }, extra_args=None, scope = "openid offline_access email", state=session["state"])
```

After running this example, I'm getting ```oic.oauth2.exception.GrantError: No grant found for state:'XXXXXXX'```

I can contribute to the repo a few easy examples about clients when I get this sorted out first. I'm not very familiar with OpenID Connect standard, so my code example might not be the prettiest.

items.title: Requesting access token refresh using refresh token via a OAuth2/OIDC client.
items.body:
According to [1] an OIDC client which previously issued an access and refresh token to the user should be allowed to refresh such access token asking the identity provider. I did not find a straightforward way to make this happen except [2]. A Grant is currently expected for most OIDC client methods, but this use-case does not seem to need any grant. Do you think OAuth2 client would be a better candidate to implement this feature ? If so, the first access token would need to be issued by OAuth2 client and not by OIDC client as the refresh tokens are bound to the client ? Is this currently implemented ? 

[1] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-6
[2] 
```
        OIDC_client = OIDC_CLIENTS[issuer]
        # assemble the request for the refresh token from the Identity Provider
        refresh_session_state = rndstr(50)
        OIDC_client.grant[refresh_session_state] = Grant()
        OIDC_client.grant[refresh_session_state].grant_expiration_time = time_util.utc_time_sans_frac() + 60
        OIDC_client.grant[refresh_session_state].code = "access_code"
        resp = AccessTokenResponse()
        resp["refresh_token"] = token_object.refresh_token
        OIDC_client.grant[refresh_session_state].tokens.append(Token(resp))
        oidc_tokens = OIDC_client.do_access_token_refresh(state=refresh_session_state)
```

items.title: Missing a capability of OAuth 2.0 client asking for token exchange using extension grant
items.body:
According to [1] and [2] an OAuth 2.0 client should be able to exchange user's token for another one with modified e.g. scopes and audiences (as defined/allowed on the side of the Identity Provider).  This does not seem to be currently implemented at all. A workaround illustrated in [3] (using an OIDC client) seems to work for the moment, but does not reflect the use case properly. 
I admit that it is not entirely clear to me, whether the token exchange should be a matter of OIDC client of OAuth 2.0 client, but I did not find another way to do this than by creating an unnecessary grant in [3]. 

[1] https://tools.ietf.org/id/draft-ietf-oauth-token-exchange-14.html#rfc.section.2
[2] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.5
[3] 
```
        OIDC_client = OIDC_CLIENTS[issuer]
        # create a grant instance of the OIDC_client
        exchange_session_state = rndstr(50)
        OIDC_client.grant[exchange_session_state] = Grant()
        OIDC_client.grant[exchange_session_state].grant_expiration_time = time_util.utc_time_sans_frac() + 60
        OIDC_client.grant[exchange_session_state].code = "exchange_code"
        resp = AccessTokenResponse()
        resp["subject_token"] = subject_token
        OIDC_client.grant[exchange_session_state].tokens.append(Token(resp))

        # assembling parameters to request a new access token
        args = {"subject_token": subject_token,
                "scope": jwt_row_dict['authz_scope'],
                "audience": jwt_row_dict['audience'],
                "grant_type": grant_type}
        # exchange access code for a access token
        oidc_token_response = OIDC_client.do_any(Message,
                                                 endpoint=OIDC_client.provider_info["token_endpoint"],
                                                 state=exchange_session_state,
                                                 request_args=args,
                                                 authn_method="client_secret_basic")

```

items.title: OAuth 2.0 client requesting token using client_credentials grant type
items.body:
According to [1], one should be allowed to make access token request with a OAuth2 client using client_credentials flow. On the client side one should not expect any grant - client_id and client_secret should be the "grant". This does not seem to be currently the case in the pyoidc library - the oauth.Client specific part. 

When one tried to ask for access token using the OAuth2.0 client, an exception is thrown informing the user about missing grant. When trying to use CCAccessTokenRequest, it does not convert it to the endpoint because line (71) of the init file is commented out - see [2] (happens also when using client.do_access_token_request function).

Workaround [3] should be possible, although not naturally reflecting the use-cases of the code design. 

This issue is an outcome of a user question in issue #724 

[1] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.4

> 4.4.1. Authorization Request and Response
> 
> Since the client authentication is used as the authorization grant,
> no additional authorization request is needed.
> 

[2]

```
client.do_any(CCAccessTokenRequest, request_args=args, authn_method="client_secret_basic")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oic/oauth2/__init__.py", line 777, in do_any
    endpoint=endpoint)

    **kwargs)

    uri = self._endpoint(self.request2endpoint[reqmsg.__name__],
KeyError: 'CCAccessTokenRequest'
from oic.oauth2.message import AccessTokenRequest
client.do_any(AccessTokenRequest, request_args=args, authn_method="client_secret_basic")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oic/oauth2/__init__.py", line 777, in do_any
    endpoint=endpoint)

items.title: Incorrect documentation for manual provider configuration
items.body:
In the Client Registration section on this page (https://pyoidc.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples/rp.html) it says that the way to manually set provider info (instead of doing automatic discovery) is 

```
op_info = ProviderConfigurationResponse(...)
client.provider_info = op_info
```

This does not work: it does not make the provider endpoints available on the client (`client.authorization_endpoint` does not return the URL).

The correct way to populate the provider info is
```
op_info = ProviderConfigurationResponse(...)
client.handle_provider_config(op_info, op_info['issuer'], False, True)
```

items.title: Client Registration with Inital Access Token does not work with Keycloak
items.body:
Hi,

The functionality to registers one's client via an initial access token
does not work with the keycloak server, maybe other Providers as well. The functionality (introduced with 7377a7a4e5e185363e)
takes an arbitrary string, base64 encodes it and adds it to a header.
Creating a registration token with keycloak already gives us an base64 encoded token. So the token gets double b64 encoded
and therefore rejected.
b64-Decoding it beforehand does not work because then we have a bytes object with a RSA Signature which cannot really be be decoded to a string object.
So, I see two possibilities:
* Add a other parameter for already b64 encoded strings
* Check if the token is b64 encoded, use it if it is, else b64- encode it.

I could implement both (or other solutions), just tell me what's more appropriate.

items.title: state no longer optional in EndSessionRequest
items.body:
In v0.15.1 `state` was optional for `EndSessionRequest`

`state` used to be `SINGLE_OPTIONAL_STRING`, but now in v1.0.1 `EndSessionRequest` subclasses `StateFullMessage` which requires `state`.

https://github.com/OpenIDC/pyoidc/commit/87466844bc9b0d9d6b50f7d7179fcd963d3026ad#diff-43dda3ff24f1b669cb65bce1dc40fdcbL797

The spec says `state` is optional
https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-session-1_0.html#RPLogout

items.title: Allow webfinger search on forced host
items.body:
According to the specification : https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7033#section-4

The host is not necessary the one on the ressource

For instance, we should be able to : 

GET https://hostONE.com/.well-known/webfinger?ressource=acct:me@hostTWO.com

>  The host to which a WebFinger query is issued is significant.  If the
   query target contains a "host" portion (Section 3.2.2 of RFC 3986),
   then the host to which the WebFinger query is issued **SHOULD** be the
   same as the "host" portion of the query target, **unless the client
   receives instructions through some out-of-band mechanism to send the
   query to another host.**  If the query target does not contain a "host"
   portion, then the client chooses a host to which it directs the query
   using additional information it has.

items.title: Client assertions
items.body:
The use of client assertions for authentication at the token endpoint in the OIDC authorization code flow is not described in the RP documentation or demonstrated in the RP examples.  This would be beneficial, and my purpose for this issue is to provide some fodder.  I specifically address using client assertions to authenticate with a Microsoft Azure AD IdP, which involves creating a custom assertion.

First, the out-of-band RP registration guidance in pyoidc's documentation only discusses registering a client using a client secret, without noting any alternative.  When using client assertions, the _client_secret_ item would obviously not be included. 

Support for client assertions is provided in the _do_access_token_request_ method of the oic.oic.Client class, using keyword arguments to the method:
```
            kwargs = dict(algorithm="RS256", authn_endpoint='token',
                          authn_method="private_key_jwt")
```
The _authn_method_ parameter initiates authentication with a client assertion.  The _algorithm_ and _authn_endpoint_ parameters are needed by the oic.utils.authn.client.PrivateKeyJWT class to properly construct the assertion.  Also required is a signing key in the client's keyjar.  A way to accomplish this is illustrated by the TestPrivateKeyJWT class in tests/test_client.py.

The payload of the resulting JWT can be understood from the _assertion_jwt_ function in oic.utils.authn.client.  Determining which header claims are generated involves more digging, and only the _alg_ claim is included.

As I stated upfront, my goal for using client assertions was authenticating at the token endpoint of a Microsoft Azure AD tenant IdP.  Microsoft provides this [guidance](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/active-directory-certificate-credentials).  The differences from the client assertion pyoicd normally generates are:

- the _typ_ and _x5t_ header claims must be included.
- the payload claim _iat_ is instead _nbf_

pyoicd nicely provides a _client_assertion_ keyword parameter when calling _client.do_access_token_request_.  The value replaces the client assertion pyoidc would normally generate.  Note that the other keyword arguments identified above are still required:
```
            kwargs = dict(algorithm="RS256", authn_endpoint='token',
                          authn_method="private_key_jwt",
                          client_assertion=custom_assertion)
```
Generating a custom client assertion for Microsoft is illustrated by the function below.
```
import json
from jwkest.jws import JWSig, SIGNER_ALGS
from jwkest.jwt import b64encode_item
from oic import rndstr
from oic.utils.time_util import utc_time_sans_frac


def make_assertion(client_id, token_endpoint, fingerprint, key, lifetime=60):
    """Creates a JWT for IdP token endpoint auth per Microsoft specs"""
    _alg = "RS256"
    headers = {'alg': _alg, 'typ': "JWT", 'x5t': fingerprint}
    _now = utc_time_sans_frac()
    payload = dict(
        iss=client_id,
        sub=client_id,
        aud=token_endpoint,
        jti=rndstr(32),
        nbf=_now,
        exp=_now + lifetime
    )
    jwt = JWSig(**headers)
    _signer = SIGNER_ALGS[_alg]
    _input = jwt.pack(parts=[json.dumps(payload)])
    sig = _signer.sign(_input.encode("utf-8"),
                       key.get_key(alg=_alg, private=True))
    return ".".join([_input, b64encode_item(sig).decode("utf-8")])
```
The _client_id_ and _token_endpoint_ arguments to this function should be straightforward.  _key_ is a _jwkest.jwk.RSAKey_.   To create one from a certificate private key file at _path_:
```
from jwkest.jwk import rsa_load, RSAKey
signing_key = RSAKey(key=rsa_load(path), kty="RSA", use='sig')
```
_fingerprint_ is a Base64 encoded SHA-1 fingerprint of the X.509 certificate corresponding to the private key.  Microsoft Azure AD displays this fingerprint as a hexadecimal string when the certificate is registered during IdP configuration.  You can easily convert this string (as _hex_string_) by:
```
from base64 import b64encode
from binascii import unhexlify
fingerprint = b64encode(unhexlify(hex_string))
```
If you don't have the hexadecimal fingerprint, but you have the X.509 certificate file, you can generate the fingerprint, as shown below using the _cryptography_ package:
```
from base64 import b64encode
from binascii import hexlify
from cryptography import x509
from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives import hashes
with open("cert.pem", "rb") as f:
    cert = x509.load_pem_x509_certificate(f.read(), default_backend())
fingerprint = cert.fingerprint(hashes.SHA1())
hexadecimal_fingerprint = hexlify(fingerprint).upper()
base64_fingerprint = b64encode(fingerprint)
```
Putting it together
```
def make_token_request(client, state, code, redirect_uri, scopes, assertion):
    """Retrieves tokens by redeeming an authorization code"""
    request_args = dict(
        client_id=client.client_id,
        code=code,
        redirect_uri=redirect_uri
    )
    kwargs = dict(
        algorithm="RS256",
        authn_endpoint='token',
        authn_method="private_key_jwt",
        client_assertion=assertion,
        request_args=request_args,
        scope=scopes,
        state=state
    )
    return client.do_access_token_request(**kwargs)
```

items.title: Deprecate refresh_db
items.body:
I think it is about time to end the duality around Refresh tokens. Both access code and access token use TokenFactory, so we should go that route as well.

The only issue I can see right now, without to much digging into is the lack of session info storage. For example, this test would fail for `DefaultToken`:

https://github.com/OpenIDC/pyoidc/blob/e94b8129c26d7c9acd1ae3c4dbfe914efedc7381/tests/test_sdb.py#L272-L287

We can either implement a storage to the `DefaultToken` or we will just assume that the `SessionDB` internal database never gets cleared?

items.title: Client secret is derived from random.random() instead of the cryptographically secure SecureRandom
items.body:
See #206 .

This time it is the client secret which gets less entropy then it should get.
https://github.com/OpenIDC/pyoidc/blob/f4781ba38fad0f299ca7d17fcff42a5ca3fdd00d/src/oic/oic/provider.py#L116

The whole construction for `secret()` is a bit weird anyway, it should probably just grab enough entropy from os.urandom(), maybe mix in some more, but no need to use a HMAC here...

items.title: Provider looses symmetric key of dynamic clients on restart
items.body:
When a client registers dynamically and requests encryption, this adds a key dervived from the client secret to the keyjar. This key will be used to encrypt userinfo and id_token responses, if the client asked for symmetric encryption. For RSA the jwks_uri provides the keys, so that works.

This is defined in:
https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#Encryption (Symmetric Encryption)

But as the keyjar has no persistence option, that symmetric key is lost during a restart, so a client trying to authenticate after an OP restarts, causes an failure to encrypt.

The key should be re-added to the keyjar as needed, as it is done during client registration:
https://github.com/OpenIDC/pyoidc/blob/f4781ba38fad0f299ca7d17fcff42a5ca3fdd00d/src/oic/oic/provider.py#L1555

Or the keyjar needs a persistence option...

items.title: Refresh token endpoint fails on bad authenticatoin method
items.body:
The recent refactoring of `token_endpoint` is causing that clients cannot access `refresh_token` as it fails on wrong authentication method used.

Since the check in `verify_client` is checking the instance of the request and the request is no longer a `RefreshAccessTokenRequest` instance.

It might be a better idea to base the check on `grant_type` present in `areq`, otherwise, we would have to rewrite the whole `token_endpoint` in `oic`.

items.title: Move Message classes to class variables
items.body:
Many methods on `Server` and `Client` take `Message` class as a `kwarg`. This creates a need to override the method if we need to change the class (especially for `Provider)`.

It might be beneficial to make them a class variable and allow to override them in `__init__` perhaps by parsing a dictionary in order to not clutter the kwargs on the init method.

items.title: Add type annotations
items.body: API on some of the methods is not quite clear. It would be helpful to add typing annotation to them.

items.title: Remove duplicated methods
items.body:
Some of the methods of `Client`, `Server` and `Provider`  in `oauth2` and `oic` packages are duplicates.

It would be beneficial to clean them up.

items.title: Key recovery can throw uncaught Exception
items.body:
When an encryption key is lost frok KeyJar (multi process setup) than a [Key recovery](https://github.com/OpenIDC/pyoidc/blob/master/src/oic/oic/provider.py#L901) process is initiated. This process has two flaws:
* Doesn't work for keys provided directly
* Can throw KeyError if the `jwks_uri` is not present in client info

items.title: Unpacking of invalid message throws uncaught exception
items.body: When an invalid JSON is passed to message init, the resulting Exception is uncaught. It should be properly handled and raises as `DecodeError`.

items.title: alabaster should not be in runtime deps
items.body:
Hi, ✋ 

As I can see the `alabaster` dependency used only for documentation in https://github.com/OpenIDC/pyoidc/blob/master/doc/conf.py#L1.
I think this dependency needed only for developers, not in install deps https://github.com/OpenIDC/pyoidc/blob/master/setup.py#L88

items.title: Do not append cookie to headers if there is none
items.body:
`oic.oauth2.provider.Provider._complete_authz()` now returns `[None]` as headers if the `cookie_func` is overriden to not do anything.

The header should be appended only if there is something to append.

items.title: JWT issuer check does not account for encrypted JWTs
items.body:
The changes in 43a03ab90a4602eea67b611f9e68fbec060f91bb do not seem to account for encrypted JWTs where the id_token `iss` value can only be checked after decrypting the token. Rather than:

1. do basic claim checks
2. verify id_token"

the process should be changed to:

1. decrypt id_token
2. do basic claim checks
3. verify id_token signature

I believe that in its turn calls for splitting the `from_jwt` method on the `IdToken` class into separate decryption and verification methods.

The alternative is to rollback this change...

items.title: Use defusedxml instead of xml
items.body: `xml` is considered unsafe. `defusedxml` provides the same functionality without the security vulnerabilities.

items.title: OpenID Connect Client - implementation questions
items.body:
Hi,

Not sure if this is the correct place to post this question, but I'm trying to integrate this library into a project that needs OpenID Connect Client functionality. Specifically, I'm following the page about how to implement a client, and I'm using the Authorization Flow (not the Implicit Flow): https://pyoidc.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples/rp.html

My attempt is working, but I had to tweak a few things regarding how it's described in the documentation, and would like to ask it here to confirm if I'm missing something.

My test has two endpoints:
* A "login" endpoint, which instantiates the client, queries the discovery document from the provider's issuer URL, and redirects to the authorization endpoint.
* A "callback" endpoint, which processes the request to redirect_uri.

The parts that I'm not sure about are:

### 1. How should the Client should be initialized in the "callback" endpoint?

The documentation says:

> Eventually a response is sent to the URL given as the redirect_uri.
> 
> You can parse this response by doing:
>
> ```
> from oic.oic.message import AuthorizationResponse
> 
> # If you're in a WSGI environment
> response = environ["QUERY_STRING"]
> 
> aresp = client.parse_response(AuthorizationResponse, info=response,
>                               sformat="urlencoded")
> 
> code = aresp["code"]
> assert aresp["state"] == session["state"]
> ```

This snippet seems to assume that "client" is already initialized from the previous steps.

However, if I'm implementing this in a framework such as Flask, the previous steps (which trigger the authorization request) would be handled by a "login" endpoint handler, and the part that handles the redirect_uri would be in a different request handler (a "callback" endpoint). Both endpoints need to initialize the Client separately.

So, this is what I ended up doing in the redirect callback handler (this is for Flask, so I'm using a different strategy for getting the QUERY_STRING):

```
    # Create OIDC Client and initialize it with provider and client information

    client = Client(client_authn_method=CLIENT_AUTHN_METHOD)
    client.provider_config(ISSUER)  # ISSUER is the issuer URL from a global variable
    client_info = {"client_id": CLIENT_ID, "client_secret": CLIENT_SECRET} # Client ID and Client Secret are gotten from global variables
    client_reg = RegistrationResponse(**client_info)
    client.store_registration_info(client_reg)

    # Handle the authorization response

    callback_resp = client.parse_response(
        AuthorizationResponse,
        info=request.query_string.decode(),
        sformat="urlencoded")

        # [...]
```

I'm creating the client similarly in both the "login" and the "callback" handlers.

It works, but I'd like to confirm if that's how I'm supposed to do it.

### 2. Correctly doing the access token request

In the documentation, there is:

```
args = {
    "code": aresp["code"]
}

resp = client.do_access_token_request(state=aresp["state"],
                                      request_args=args,
                                      authn_method="client_secret_basic")
```

However, when trying to do that, I get an error:
```
oic.oauth2.message.MissingRequiredAttribute: Missing required attribute 'redirect_uri'
```

To make it work, I tried to adapt it by including the redirect_uri and then it worked:

```
    access_resp = client.do_access_token_request(
        state=callback_resp['state'],
        request_args={
            'code': callback_resp['code']#,
            "redirect_uri": current_app.config["HOSTNAME"]+'/callback'
        },
        authn_method="client_secret_basic",
    )
```

Should this be corrected in the documentation?

Thank you.

items.title: Uncaught error in _verify_sector_identifier
items.body: If the provided `sector_identifier` is not a valid URL, the error from `requests` is uncaught and ServerError is raised instead of returning an expected `InvalidSectorIdentifier`.

items.title: UnicodeDecodeError in verify_redirect_uri
items.body:
The code in `oic.provider.Provider.verify_redirect_uris` fails with `UnicodeDecodeError` if the `redirect_uri` in request contains unicode characters.

This is due to a bug in `future.backports.urllib.parse.urlparse`, the best solution is to use `urlparse` from `future.moves`.

items.title: Drop support for python 2
items.body:
I think that it is about time we drop support for python 2. The remaining lifetime is only one year and dropping this support would allow some much needed code cleanup.

We should do a last release which would support both versions of python towards the end of the year and then drop python 2 entirely in 2019.

If we agree on this, I can focus on that.

items.title: Support specifying requests timeout
items.body:
By default `requests` does not use timeouts, so it can hang forever. Production code using requests should almost always specify a timeout.
http://docs.python-requests.org/en/master/user/advanced/#timeouts

I can subclass `oic.oic.Client` to forward a timeout for most of pyoidc requests usage:

```python
class Client(oic.oic.Client):
    def http_request(self, *args, **kwargs):
        # Set requests timeout for all http connections pyoidc makes
        kwargs["timeout"] = (3.05, 10)
        return super(Client, self).http_request(*args, **kwargs)
```

But pyoidc fetches keys without specifying any timeout or using the above Client to make the request, see `KeyBundle.do_remote`
https://github.com/OpenIDC/pyoidc/blob/master/src/oic/utils/keyio.py#L168

items.title: Missing project description at PyPI
items.body:
At the moment, it's very hard (nearly impossible) to find `pyoidc` on Python Package Index ([PyPI](https://pypi.org/)), as it doesn't show up for an intuitive search query `openid`:

![](https://i.imgur.com/nxZvR1l.png)

Also, if you search for `oidc`, you also get unrelated packages: https://pypi.org/search/?q=oidc

You can only find pyoidc by searching for `oic`, which is not a common acronym and doesn't even correspond to its GitHub repo.

Despite being just 1 of 2 Python packages certified by OpenID, the `oic` package on PyPI is missing any description, looks totally unmaintained and abandoned, certainly doesn't look like something you want to use for security purposes: https://pypi.org/project/oic/

Low version of the package (`0.14.0`) also averts the users compared to some other packages that claim to be version `1.x` and `2.x`.

PyPI is the go-to place for most Python developers and not being able to find a mature implementation of OpenID spec will lead people to using immature unverified libraries.

---

So is `pyoidc` still considered the go-to library for OpenID Connect implementation or is there anything more mature on PyPI?

If it still is, improving project description and adding relative keywords on PyPI would really help the project to be more visible. Because the only practical way to find it right now is to go to https://openid.net/developers/certified/ which, unfortunately, not many people do (most just do `pip search`).

I'm not sure if this is something that can be done via pull-request (I think PyPI description is managed by the maintainer who uploads the package), but if there are ways to help with this, please let me know.

items.title: Redirect ans SeeOther responses (from http_util) are not compliant with WSGI specs
items.body:
and do not work at all on python3.

in WSGI specs for start_response() we can read:

> The status argument is an HTTP "status" string like "200 OK" or "404 Not Found". 

(from https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3333/#the-start-response-callable).

Implementation of the __call__() method for the  Response class seems correct
```
   def __call__(self, environ, start_response, **kwargs):
        name = http_client.responses.get(self.status_code, 'UNKNOWN')
        start_response("{} {}".format(self.status_code, name), self.headers)
        return self.response(self.message, **kwargs)
```

but this method is overridden in Redirect as (SeeOther is similar):
```
    def __call__(self, environ, start_response, **kwargs):
        location = self.message
        self.headers.append(('location', location))
        start_response(self.status_code, self.headers)
        return self.response((location, location, location))
```

in which the status_code is not formatted as a string before calling the start_method callback.

This code works with python2 due an unexpected side effect, but does not on Python3 (prevent rp3 example from working (among other problems)).

items.title: extra_claims in token.py not used for anything other than 'kid'
items.body:
In https://github.com/OpenIDC/pyoidc/blob/f1d7e29a3d60fa7bfc5b65a30be211a786839a8e/doc/examples/op.rst#extension-of-supported-claims-and-scopes, it is said 
`extra_claims` is used to support extra claims.  But in https://github.com/OpenIDC/pyoidc/blob/release.0.14.0/src/oic/extension/token.py, this information is only ever read in `kwargs['kid'] = self.extra_claims['kid']`.  That is, only key id is ever read from extra_claims regardless of what is actually in extra_claims.  

Am I misunderstanding this? I am relatively new to OIDC.
Also, related to my own issues in trying to use pyoidc, if I wanted to add anything to pass to an api, say some kind of user info like name or account number, how would I be able to do that if the claims are not processed?

items.title: Bug in the processing logic of the fetch_distributed_claims() method
items.body:
Said method in pyoidc/src/oic/oic/__init__.py  iterates through the _claim_sources and adds the _claim_names it finds to the userinfo response. The bug in the logic is the *adding* instead of real derefering (that is, *substituting*), because the userinfo response looks in the end like this:

` {     "_claim_names": {         "name": "b09493f0-f223-48e5-8058-59370a47cc52"     },     "_claim_sources": {         "b09493f0-f223-48e5-8058-59370a47cc52": {             "access_token": "XXX",             "endpoint": "https://iagent.freedom-id.de/user-info-endpoint"         }     },     "name": "Value of name",     "sub": "4AOKNFYHf55AXmbmr9VLuoQ2+x0AtXsKe6m3m5Vxlei+1gh6tJLeXnt76MAGfcXd" }
`

And that doesn't make any sense.

FWIW this bug is what triggers the openid-certification/oidctest#81 behavior.

items.title: Refactor get_client_id

As pointed out in #510 `get_client_id` has an unused part of code (branch with checking for the `rat` without presence of `client_id` in request).

Since `client_id` is a required attribute of AuthenticationRequest, we shouldn't do this and throw an error instead.

items.title: utils.http_util.Response uses invalid status arguments to WSGI start_response
items.body:
Introduced by the refactoring of status/status_code in #495 

Response calls the WSGI defined `start_response` callback with the integer status code directly.
According to the docs, the first argument must be a string not an integer.

https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0333/#the-start-response-callable

> The status argument is an HTTP "status" string like "200 OK" or "404 Not Found". That is, it is a string consisting of a Status-Code and a Reason-Phrase, in that order and separated by a single space, with no surrounding whitespace or other characters. (See RFC 2616, Section 6.1.1 for more information.) The string must not contain control characters, and must not be terminated with a carriage return, linefeed, or combination thereof.

Probably just needs something like:

    name = httplib.responses.get(status_code, 'UNKNOWN')
    status = "%d %s" % (status_code, name)

items.title: Drop duplicate structure of CDB
items.body:
CDB now needs to keep two mappings for clients. One for `client_id` and one for `_rat`.

The access by `_rat` is used only in `oic.oic.Provider.read_registration` where it can be easily removed by switching the order of checks.

The client info would be retrieved using `client_id` in request and the correct `_rat`  will be checked.

Brought up in #499 as well.

items.body:
I use this lib and face this problem:
 - On every oic_client do_access_token_refresh method call my app leaks about 8-9KB.

I started to figure out the problem and found this:
 in oic Client class all tokens stored in grants dictionaries. All tokens is stored - outdated or not. So when I request new access and refresh token by refresh request, old one will stay there.

So in my app I wrote this code, to delete outdated tokens (based on refresh_token expired)

```        
        now = time.time()
        # Preventing oic client from memory leaking
        oic_token_to_delete = [
            (state, token)
            for (state, grant) in self._oic_client.grant.items()
            for token in grant.tokens
            if now > token.id_token['iat'] + token.refresh_expires_in
        ]
        if oic_token_to_delete:
            LOG.debug('Outdated OIC tokens deleted %s'

items.title: Add support for extra_scopes
items.body:
There is a possibility to support extra scopes. This should be easily possible.

Proposal:
* Add `extra_scope_dict` kwarg to `oic.oic.Provider` and use them in `ProviderConfiguration`
* Remove extraneous `openid` scope
* Add `extra_scope_dict` kwarg to `oic.oic.scope2claims`
* Pass this kwarg to `scope2claims` in `oic.oic.Provider._collect_user_info()`

items.title: distributed claims verification
items.body:
Pyoidc seems to have incomplete support for handing distributed claims (http://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#AggregatedDistributedClaims). 

When verifying the JWT returned from the distributed claim endpoint it will try and use the key material from the "main" Provider. Instead it should:
  a) get the key material for the Provider that actually generated the JWT using Discovery with the `iss` value, or
  b) it should omit verification since the JWT is obtained from a TLS protected endpoint
Admittedly the spec is not clear on the verification part but the current implementation is broken since the wrong key material is used.

items.title: SystemRandom is not imported correctly
items.body:
In `src/oic/__init__.py`, `random.SystemRandom` is imported via the following code:
```
try:
    import random.SystemRandom as rnd
except ImportError:
    import random as rnd
```

In both python2 and python3 this yields an import error and falls back to the `random` package.

I believe the fix is to change the import to `from random import SystemRandom as rnd`. The import works locally for me but I am having some trouble with the unit tests and wanted to check in before opening a pull request.

items.title: Configuring non-default CA certificates for a KeyJar does not work as expected

milestone.title: P2: SHOULD
milestone.description: Changes that are advisable and should take secondary priority to P1.

items.body:
The KeyJar constructor takes two TLS related arguments 'verify_ssl' (default=True) and 'ca_certs' (default: None). 

Trying to configure a non-default CA like this fails with a when fetching keys:

    kj = KeyJar(ca_certs=mycerts, verify_ssl=True)
    Client(ca_certs=mycerts, verify_ssl=True, keyjar=kj, ...)

It also fails to just use the defaults and just configure the client without an explicit keyjar:

    Client(ca_certs=mycerts, verify_ssl=True, ...)

The ca_certs parameter to KeyJar is stored, but never used. The KeyBundle Class only ever sees the verify_ssl parameter that is passed down to requests.

The default KeyJar setup in PBase.__init__ is also broken, so you need to set BOTH verify_ssl and ca_certs to a path to make it work properly. PBase gets it right for its own http_request code though, but fails to setup the default KeyJar correctly.

items.title: Mark ldap as optional dependency
items.body:
Brought up in #409...

`ldap` can be marked as an optional dependency in `setup.py`. The imports should be surrounded by `try` and throw `ImproperlyConfigured` if `ldap` is not installed.

Test requiring `ldap` should be skipped if `ldap` is not installed.

When one performs a request on read_registration endpoint with wrong authentication info, uncaught exception is raised (https://github.com/OpenIDC/pyoidc/blob/master/src/oic/oic/provider.py#L1637).

The KeyError should be expected and server should return `error_response`.

Also `assert` on line 1641 should be replaced by some other checking mechanism because of optimalizations.

items.title: NoSuitableSigningKeys Error
items.body:
I am implementing an oidc client. I registered the client (b2note) to the provider (b2access) manually. In the authorization code flow, when I try to query for the access token with the function do_acces_token_request, as described in the example [1], I get the error NoSuitableSigningKeys, No key for algorithm: RS256. How to solve this?

relevant code:
[views.txt](https://github.com/OpenIDC/pyoidc/files/1496858/views.txt)


[1] http://pyoidc.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples/rp.html

items.title: SeeOther has no 'Location' header
items.body:
Hello. I have class LDAPAuth(oic.utils.authn.user.UserAuthnMethod).
and implemented method "verify" where i do next (check if user exists on ldap server and then authorize him if true):

```py
authz_request = AuthorizationRequest().from_dict(query)  
return self.srv.authz_part2(username, authz_request, session_id)
```
Method authz_part2 returns a SeeOther response and I return this as a response to browser. But this response without a location header and browser just prints redirect url on the page instead of redirecting.
For now I just check if method "verify" returns "SeeOther" response then I add location header manually.
Please help me maybe I'm doing something wrong?
Thank you.

items.title: persistent Session DB storage
items.body:
Good day,
for now SessionDB in-memory solution, this mean that after application restart all "authorized" users flush and need again pass authorization.

What is right way to support persistent storage? Or maybe there are any "ready to use" solutions?
